title: Schizophrenia symptoms and functioning in patients receiving long-term treatment with olanzapine long-acting injection formulation: a pooled analysis
abstract: This analysis of pooled data evaluates treatment outcomes of patients with schizophrenia receiving maintenance treatment with olanzapine long-acting injection (OLAI) by means of a categorical approach addressing the symptomatic and functional status of patients at different times.Patients were grouped into 5 categories at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Shifts between categories were assessed for individual patients and factors associated with improvement were analyzed. 1182 patients from 3 clinical trials were included in the current analysis.At baseline, 434 (36.8%) patients had minimal Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) symptoms but seriously impaired Heinrich Carpenter's Quality of Life Scale (QLS) functioning; 303 (25.6%) had moderate to severe symptoms and seriously impaired function; 208 (17.6%) had mild to moderate symptoms but good functioning, and 162 (13.7%) had minimal symptoms and good functioning. Baseline category was significantly associated with Clinical Global Impression--Severity (CGI-S), extrapyramidal symptoms, working status, age, and number of previous episodes. The majority of all patients starting OLAI treatment maintained or improved (62% at 6 months and 52% at 12 months) their symptom and functioning levels on OLAI maintenance treatment. Less than 8% of the patients showed worsening of symptoms or functioning. An improvement in category was associated with high PANSS positive and low CGI-S scores at baseline.We present evidence that a composite assessment of schizophrenic patients including symptom severity and functioning is helpful in the evaluation of maintenance treatment outcomes. This approach could also be useful for the assessment of treatment options in clinical practice.The trials from which data are reported here were registered on clinicaltrials.gov as NCT00088491, NCT00088465, and NCT00320489.

motivations: There is a need to evaluate the effectiveness of long-term treatment with olanzapine long-acting injection (OLAI) in patients with schizophrenia.
Understanding the relationship between symptom severity and functioning in patients with schizophrenia can help improve treatment outcomes.
objectives: Assess the symptomatic and functional status of patients with schizophrenia receiving OLAI treatment using a categorical approach.
Evaluate the shifts in symptom and functioning categories over time and identify factors associated with improvement.
methods: Analyze pooled data from three clinical trials using a categorical approach to evaluate treatment outcomes.
Assess symptom severity and functioning using standardized scales such as PANSS and QLS.
Examine the association between baseline category and various factors, including CGI-S, extrapyramidal symptoms, and working status.
results: The majority of patients maintained or improved their symptom and functioning levels on OLAI maintenance treatment.
Less than 8% of patients showed worsening of symptoms or functioning.
A composite assessment of symptom severity and functioning is helpful in evaluating maintenance treatment outcomes.

motivations: Traditional assessments of schizophrenia treatment outcomes often focus on symptoms alone without adequately considering functional status.
There is a need for comprehensive evaluation approaches that combine both symptomatic and functional outcomes to better understand treatment effectiveness in schizophrenia patients.
objectives: Evaluate treatment outcomes in schizophrenia patients receiving olanzapine long-acting injection using a categorical approach that combines symptomatic and functional status.
Identify factors associated with improvement and analyze shifts between patient categories over time.
methods: Pooled data analysis from three clinical trials categorizing patients into 5 groups based on PANSS symptoms and QLS functioning scores.
Assessment of categorical shifts at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months to track individual patient changes.
Statistical analysis to identify factors associated with improvement including CGI-S scores, extrapyramidal symptoms, and demographic variables.
results: The majority of patients maintained or improved their symptom and functioning levels with less than 8% showing worsening.
Improvement was associated with high PANSS positive scores and low CGI-S scores at baseline.
The composite assessment approach demonstrated utility in evaluating maintenance treatment outcomes beyond traditional symptom-focused measures.
